nameEntry.part: Open All Night Refuge for Women
Open All Night Refuge for Friendless Women

biogHist.abstract: The Open All Night Refuge was established in Darlinghurst by George Edward Ardill in 1883, via the Blue Ribbon Gospel Army, which later became the Sydney Rescue Work Society. It provided temporary accommodation for women and children, including those fleeing domestic violence. It also took in alcoholics and prostitutes. It moved to Surry Hills in 1884, then Sussex Street, Sydney in 1890, then in 1907 moved to Little Hay. By 1933 it was in Surry Hills. It closed in the 1950s.
biogHist.p: George Ardill and his wife Louisa provided regular gospel temperance services at the refuge, offered beds and meals and tried to find work for those seeking aid. Each night it accommodated around 30 women and six children. Single mothers seeking longer term assistance were, at least in the early years, likely to be encouraged to send their children to the State Children's Relief Board, so most women stayed for the shortest possible time.

Initially the Open All Night Refuge was co-located with the Home of Hope for Friendless and Fallen Women in Darlinghurst, but the organisations were separated in 1884. In 1886 it moved to 34 Cooper Street, Surry Hills. By 1890 it had moved to 403 Sussex Street, Sydney. By 1907 it was in Little Hay and Harbour Streets. Bogle reports that it was based in Commonwealth Street, Surry Hills by 1911.

According to The Australian Women's Weekly, in 1933 the Open All Night Refuge was in the same spot, with its entrance on Beauchamp Lane, Surry Hills. The The Australian Women's Weekly said children were taken in with their mothers by the Open All Night Refuge, and temporary food and shelter was provided for them.

Ardill promoted the refuge as 'welcoming' in his Sydney Rescue Work Society newsletter The Rescue in the 1890s but former Communicare CEO and Sydney Rescue Work Society historian Bruce Thornton records that journalists at the time said the refuge 'dismally hovered over the street', was 'wretchedly furnished' and had a 'mean and forbidding' atmosphere. This austerity was something Ardill and his followers considered necessary to ensure the reformation of alcoholics.
